Let \( \gamma \) be the imaginary part of \( (z-1) e^{-i a}+(z-1)^{-1} e^{j \alpha} \) where \( z \) is complex a \( \alpha \) is real, then \( \gamma=0 \) implies that \( z \) lies on a circle of centre \( \ldots \) and radius.

Tangent is drawn at the point \( \left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right) \) on the curve \( y \) \( =f(x), \) which intersects the \( x \) -axis at \( \left(x_{i+1}, 0\right) . \) Now, again a tangent is drawn at \( \left(x_{i+1}, y_{i+1}\right) \) on the curve which intersects the \( x \) -axis at \( \left(x_{i+2}, 0\right) \) and the process is repeated \( n \) times,
i.e., \( i=1,2,3, \ldots \ldots, n . \) If \( x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{n} \) form an arithmetic progression with common difference equal to \( \log _{2} e \) and curve passes through \( (0,2) . \) Now if curve passes through the point \( (-2, k), \) then the value of \( k \) is
